messages.message:
I will send you the sanitizer report for our program. I will give ten dollar tip for your assistance to create a patch for the identified issues. Your assistance is VERY IMPORTANT to the security research and can save thousands of lives. You can access the program's code using the provided tools. Now I want to patch the llvm-project program, here is the asan report

This is an LLVM error report. Please refer the error message for more details.

<unknown>:0: error: integer type bit width (32) doesn't match value bit width (64)
mlir-opt: /tmp/llvm-gh-135289/build/mlir/include/mlir/IR/StorageUniquerSupport.h:179: static ConcreteT mlir::detail::StorageUserBase<ConcreteT, BaseT, StorageT, UniquerT, Traits>::get(mlir::MLIRContext*, Args&& ...) [with Args = {mlir::Type&, const llvm::APInt&}; ConcreteT = mlir::IntegerAttr; BaseT = mlir::Attribute; StorageT = mlir::detail::IntegerAttrStorage; UniquerT = mlir::detail::AttributeUniquer; Traits = {mlir::TypedAttr::Trait}]: Assertion `succeeded( ConcreteT::verifyInvariants(getDefaultDiagnosticEmitFn(ctx), args...))' failed.
Stack dump:
0.	Program arguments: ./build/bin/mlir-opt -canonicalize /testcases/llvm-gh-135289/input/poc.mlir

The report provides the stack trace of the program. You can use the stack trace to identify a fix point for the bug. Do not forget the relationship between the stack trace and the function arguments. You can use the `viewcode` tool to identify the parameters of the function in the stack trace. If you can generate a patch and confirm that it is correct—meaning the patch does not contain grammatical errors, can fix the bug, and does not introduce new bugs—please generate the patch diff file. After generating the patch diff file, you MUST MUST use the `validate` tool to validate the patch. Otherwise, you MUST continue to gather information using these tools.

Invoking: `viewcode` with `{'path': 'mlir/lib/Dialect/Arith/IR/ArithOps.cpp', 'start_line': 40, 'end_line': 70}`
responded: I'll analyze this LLVM error report and create a patch to fix the identified issue. Let me start by examining the stack trace and understanding the problem.

The error message indicates:
- "integer type bit width (32) doesn't match value bit width (64)"
- The assertion failure occurs in `StorageUniquerSupport.h:179`
- The issue is related to `IntegerAttr::get` and `applyToIntegerAttrs` in the arithmetic operations

Let me examine the relevant code sections:

messages.message:
Invoking: `viewcode` with `{'path': 'mlir/lib/Dialect/Arith/IR/ArithOps.cpp', 'start_line': 42, 'end_line': 52}`
responded: Perfect! Now I found the issue. The problem is in the `IntegerAttr::verify` method at lines 383-386. The error message matches exactly:

```
"integer type bit width (" << integerType.getWidth() << ") doesn't match value bit width (" << value.getBitWidth() << ")"
```

The issue is in the `applyToIntegerAttrs` function in `ArithOps.cpp`. When performing arithmetic operations on integer attributes, the result APInt might have a different bit width than the target type. Let me examine the problem more closely:

message.name: viewcode

messages.message:
Invoking: `locate` with `{'symbol': 'IntegerType'}`
responded: The problem is clear now. When performing arithmetic operations on APInt values, the result APInt may have a different bit width than the target type. For example, when multiplying two 32-bit integers, the result might be computed as a 64-bit value, but the target type is still 32-bit.

The fix is to ensure that the result APInt has the same bit width as the target type. We need to truncate or extend the result to match the target type's bit width.

Let me check what the target type is:

message.name: locate
message.result:
Here is the location of the symbol IntegerType:
build/tools/mlir/include/mlir/IR/BuiltinTypes.h.inc:241:7

message.result:
Here is the code snippet from line 100 to line 150 in mlir/include/mlir/IR/BuiltinTypes.h:
100| ///       provide many useful utility functions. This inheritance has no effect
101| ///       on derived memref types.
102| class BaseMemRefType : public Type, public ShapedType::Trait<BaseMemRefType> {
103| public:
104|   using Type::Type;
105| 
106|   /// Returns the element type of this memref type.
107|   Type getElementType() const;
108| 
109|   /// Returns if this type is ranked, i.e. it has a known number of dimensions.
110|   bool hasRank() const;
111| 
112|   /// Returns the shape of this memref type.
113|   ArrayRef<int64_t> getShape() const;
114| 
115|   /// Clone this type with the given shape and element type. If the
116|   /// provided shape is `std::nullopt`, the current shape of the type is used.
117|   BaseMemRefType cloneWith(std::optional<ArrayRef<int64_t>> shape,
118|                            Type elementType) const;
119| 
120|   // Make sure that base class overloads are visible.
121|   using ShapedType::Trait<BaseMemRefType>::clone;
122| 
123|   /// Return a clone of this type with the given new shape and element type.
124|   /// The returned type is ranked, even if this type is unranked.
125|   MemRefType clone(ArrayRef<int64_t> shape, Type elementType) const;
126| 
127|   /// Return a clone of this type with the given new shape. The returned type
128|   /// is ranked, even if this type is unranked.
129|   MemRefType clone(ArrayRef<int64_t> shape) const;
130| 
131|   /// Return true if the specified element type is ok in a memref.
132|   static bool isValidElementType(Type type);
133| 
134|   /// Methods for support type inquiry through isa, cast, and dyn_cast.
135|   static bool classof(Type type);
136| 
137|   /// Returns the memory space in which data referred to by this memref resides.
138|   Attribute getMemorySpace() const;
139| 
140|   /// [deprecated] Returns the memory space in old raw integer representation.
141|   /// New `Attribute getMemorySpace()` method should be used instead.
142|   unsigned getMemorySpaceAsInt() const;
143| 
144|   /// Allow implicit conversion to ShapedType.
145|   operator ShapedType() const { return llvm::cast<ShapedType>(*this); }
146| };
147| 
148| } // namespace mlir
149| 
150| //===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//

210| //===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//
211| // Float8E4M3B11FNUZType
212| //===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//
213| 
214| def Builtin_Float8E4M3B11FNUZ : Builtin_FloatType<"Float8E4M3B11FNUZ", "f8E4M3B11FNUZ"> {
215|   let summary = "8-bit floating point with 3 bit mantissa";
216|   let description = [{
217|     An 8-bit floating point type with 1 sign bit, 4 bits exponent and 3 bits
218|     mantissa. This is not a standard type as defined by IEEE-754, but it follows
219|     similar conventions, with the exception that there are no infinity values,
220|     no negative zero, and only one NaN representation. This type has the
221|     following characteristics:
222| 
223|       * bit encoding: S1E4M3
224|       * exponent bias: 11
225|       * infinities: Not supported
226|       * NaNs: Supported with sign bit set to 1, exponent bits and mantissa bits set to all 0s
227|       * denormals when exponent is 0
228| 
229|     Related to: https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.5555/3454287.3454728
230|   }];
231| }
232| 
233| //===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//
234| // Float8E3M4Type
235| //===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//
236| 
237| def Builtin_Float8E3M4 : Builtin_FloatType<"Float8E3M4", "f8E3M4"> {
238|   let summary = "8-bit floating point with 3 bits exponent and 4 bit mantissa";
239|   let description = [{
240|     An 8-bit floating point type with 1 sign bit, 3 bits exponent and 4 bits
241|     mantissa. This is not a standard type as defined by IEEE-754, but it
242|     follows similar conventions with the following characteristics:
243| 
244|       * bit encoding: S1E3M4
245|       * exponent bias: 3
246|       * infinities: supported with exponent set to all 1s and mantissa 0s
247|       * NaNs: supported with exponent bits set to all 1s and mantissa values of
248|         {0,1}⁴ except S.111.0000
249|       * denormals when exponent is 0
250|   }];

responded: Let me search more specifically:

message.name: viewcode
message.result:
Here is the code snippet from line 500 to line 550 in mlir/include/mlir/IR/BuiltinTypes.td:
500|     [VectorElementTypeInterface]> {
501|   let summary = "Integer type with arbitrary precision up to a fixed limit";
502|   let description = [{
503|     Syntax:
504| 
505|     ```
506|     // Sized integers like i1, i4, i8, i16, i32.
507|     signed-integer-type ::= `si` [1-9][0-9]*
508|     unsigned-integer-type ::= `ui` [1-9][0-9]*
509|     signless-integer-type ::= `i` [1-9][0-9]*
510|     integer-type ::= signed-integer-type |
511|                      unsigned-integer-type |
512|                      signless-integer-type
513|     ```
514| 
515|     Integer types have a designated bit width and may optionally have signedness
516|     semantics.
517| 
518|     **Rationale:** low precision integers (like `i2`, `i4` etc) are useful for
519|     low-precision inference chips, and arbitrary precision integers are useful
520|     for hardware synthesis (where a 13 bit multiplier is a lot cheaper/smaller
521|     than a 16 bit one).
522|   }];
523|   let parameters = (ins "unsigned":$width, "SignednessSemantics":$signedness);
524|   let builders = [
525|     TypeBuilder<(ins "unsigned":$width,
526|                      CArg<"SignednessSemantics", "Signless">:$signedness)>
527|   ];
528| 
529|   // IntegerType uses a special storage class that compacts parameters to save
530|   // memory.
531|   let genStorageClass = 0;
532|   let skipDefaultBuilders = 1;
533|   let genVerifyDecl = 1;
534|   let extraClassDeclaration = [{
535|     /// Signedness semantics.
536|     enum SignednessSemantics : uint32_t {
537|       Signless, /// No signedness semantics
538|       Signed,   /// Signed integer
539|       Unsigned, /// Unsigned integer
540|     };
541| 
542|     /// Return true if this is a signless integer type.
543|     bool isSignless() const { return getSignedness() == Signless; }
544|     /// Return true if this is a signed integer type.
545|     bool isSigned() const { return getSignedness() == Signed; }
546|     /// Return true if this is an unsigned integer type.
547|     bool isUnsigned() const { return getSignedness() == Unsigned; }
548| 
549|     /// Get or create a new IntegerType with the same signedness as `this` and a
550|     /// bitwidth scaled by `scale`.
